September 20, 1998: Fiction
RAINBOW SIX, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $27.95.) John Clark, heading an
international task force, investigates terrorist incidents in Switzerland, Germany
and Spain.
TELL ME YOUR DREAMS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $26.) A series of brutal
murders that may involve three young women leads to a bizarre trial and a
defense based on startling medical evidence.
I KNOW THIS MUCH IS TRUE, by Wally Lamb. (Regan Books/HarperCollins,
$27.50.) A troubled man must care for his schizophrenic identical-twin brother and
face the nightmares that have bedeviled their family.
THE FIRST EAGLE, by Tony Hillerman. (HarperCollins, $25.) Two Navajo
policemen pursue a mysterious killer -- a plague or a person? -- in the Southwest.
NO SAFE PLACE, by Richard North Patterson. (Knopf, $25.95.) The perils
suffered by a senator running for President in the year 2000.
MEMOIRS OF A GEISHA, by Arthur Golden. (Knopf, $25.) The life of a young
woman growing up in Kyoto who has to reinvent herself after World War II begins.
SUMMER SISTERS, by Judy Blume. (Delacorte, $21.95.) Two young women from
very different backgrounds come of age together on Martha's Vineyard.
MESSAGE IN A BOTTLE, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $20.) After finding a
seaborne bottle containing an enigmatic letter, a divorced woman encounters love.
POINT OF ORIGIN, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $25.95.) Dr. Kay Scarpetta
battles an old enemy, a serial killer who has escaped and is resuming her crimes.
BRIDGET JONES'S DIARY, by Helen Fielding. (Viking, $22.95.) A year in the life
of a 30-something single woman in London.
A WIDOW FOR ONE YEAR, by John Irving. (Random House, $27.95.) Three
looks at the complex emotional life of a writer and single mother.
A NIGHT WITHOUT ARMOR, by Jewel Kilcher. (HarperCollins, $15.) The singer-
songwriter's poems contemplate love, family, Alaska and life on the road.
VISION OF THE FUTURE, by Timothy Zahn. (Spectra/ Bantam, $24.95.) Han
Solo, Luke Skywalker and Princess Leia of ''Star Wars'' struggle to prevent a civil
war.
THE STREET LAWYER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A young lawyer
comes to terms with himself after discovering his prestigious firm's dirty secret.
MOON MUSIC, by Faye Kellerman. (Morrow, $25.50.) Detective Romulus Poe's
September 20, 1998
Non-Fiction
THE DAY DIANA DIED, by Christopher Andersen. (Morrow, $27.) An account of
the events surrounding the death of the Princess of Wales.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A sportswriter
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
A PIRATE LOOKS AT FIFTY, by Jimmy Buffett. (Random House, $24.95.) While
traveling from the Florida Keys to the Amazon, the singer-songwriter reflects on
his half-century of life.
THE DEATH OF OUTRAGE, by William J. Bennett. (Free Press, $20.) The former
Secretary of Education takes a critical view of the Clinton Presidency.
ANGELA'S ASHES, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $25.) An Irish-American writer
recalls his childhood amid the miseries of Limerick.
A WALK IN THE WOODS, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway, $25.) A journalist finds
beauty and humor while hiking the Appalachian Trail.
THE MILLIONAIRE NEXT DOOR, by Thomas J. Stanley and William D. Danko.
(Longstreet, $22.) An analysis of the lives of wealthy Americans.
CONVERSATIONS WITH GOD: Book 1, by Neale Donald Walsch. (Putnam,
$19.95.) The author addresses questions of life and love, good and evil, guilt and
sin.
DIANA: Portrait of a Princess, by Jayne Fincher and Judy Wade. (Callaway/Simon
& Schuster, $35.) More than 500 photographs of the Princess of Wales.
A MONK SWIMMING, by Malachy McCourt. (Hyperion, $23.95.) The writer and
actor (and brother of Frank McCourt) remembers his life in America and Ireland.
WE ARE OUR MOTHERS' DAUGHTERS, by Cokie Roberts. (Morrow, $19.95.)
The television news anchor's personal reflections on women in politics and
business and as mothers, wives, sisters and friends.
THE GIFTS OF THE JEWS, by Thomas Cahill. (Talese/ Doubleday, $23.50.)
What Western civilization owes an ancient nomadic tribe.
THE ROARING 2000s, by Harry S. Dent Jr. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) An
economist discusses the prospects for the upcoming millennium.
CITIZEN SOLDIERS, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) The
United States Army from Normandy to the Bulge to Germany's surrender.
TITAN, by Ron Chernow. (Random House, $30.) The life of John D. Rockefeller
Sr.
